26.28.text: is the BBC's disability correspondent Nikki Fox.

32.96.text: The comedian and presenter Iain Stirling

35.88.text: answers questions on the films of Robin Williams.

45.88.text: And the 6 Music presenter Chris Hawkins.

48.72.text: He's answering questions on Coronation Street.

60.44.text: Hello and welcome to Celebrity Mastermind,

64.68.text: Four contenders who have made a great success of their lives,

67.84.text: but now face a challenge that is daunting, even for them.

73.48.text: their reward is the honour of becoming a Celebrity Mastermind,

77.16.text: at least for one of them.

80.60.text: a minute and a half on their specialist subject,

82.72.text: and then two minutes on general knowledge.

85.20.text: So, let's ask our first contender to join us, please.

676.20.text: is the range of the ages of the children who watch,

679.92.text:
- Six to about 12. They get a bit old then.

686.08.text: Because at that age it's an enormous wide...

700.44.text: I think they find the same stuff as adults funny,

708.60.text:

- Yeah, but again, bridging the gap?

724.68.text: Thank you for having me. Appreciate it. I'll chuck you a fart later.

912.88.text: Why is now... We've never had one in the BBC before.

916.00.text: Why is now the time for us to have a disability correspondent,

920.68.text: Well, I think it's... I think BBC News themselves,

923.24.text: the people that I work with, the big bosses,

925.24.text: they recognise that as much as they were trying,

927.92.text: they weren't getting the stories that mattered to disabled people

931.48.text: on, you know, the six o'clock news, the ten o'clock news,

934.04.text: as much as they wanted to, you know.

938.88.text: ..and I think that's a great step forward, really.

943.52.text: I mean, is it to raise the profile of people with disabilities,

947.80.text: the problems that they face, or is it to be a journalist?

951.84.text: Because, I mean, it's quite difficult to do both.

954.16.text: I am a journalist, the same as the health correspondent,

959.12.text: so, you know, I am a correspondent, I am a journalist,

961.80.text: and I just want to put stories on the six o'clock, ten o'clock news,

965.20.text: do a really good job with them,

966.68.text: make them as accessible as possible, yeah.

1167.60.text:

1597.92.text: which holds the bulk of the nation's gold reserves?

1603.24.text: was among the first in Britain to create abstract works?

1607.48.text: ..name is given... I've started so I'll finish.

1609.56.text: ..to the sweet secretion from plant blossom that bees

1612.00.text: use as the raw material to make honey?

1616.52.text: The title of the Lloyd Webber sequel was Love Never Dies,

1636.60.text: Let's have a look at all the scores.

1638.24.text: In fourth place, 11 points, Nikki Fox.

1668.96.text: You're so kind, that looks amazing.

1670.88.text:
- Historically, where does that rate, you know, or rank? 
- Oh, amazing.

1675.24.text: I never thought... I think you...

1676.72.text: This is my grandma's favourite programme

1678.88.text: when I was a little girl, so we watched it all the time

1681.24.text: and she used to watch, saying, "Ooh, those people are clever!" So...

1687.04.text:
- Well done. 
- Thank you so much. 
- Congratulations. 
- Thank you, John.

1689.84.text: Now, you do not have to be a celebrity to take part

1694.20.text: If you'd like to appear in the next series on BBC Two

1696.68.text: then do visit us online at...

1700.64.text: ..and you can follow us on Twitter at...

1704.44.text: ..and do join us again next time, for more Mastermind.
